Dodgers Reading Champions Challenge

The Los Angeles Dodgers and Los Angeles Dodgers Foundation are excited to offer the Dodgers Reading Champions Challenge as a part of the LA Reads literacy initiative and efforts to support at-home learning during the COVID-19 pandemic. From home, you can easily join online and keep students engaged and excited to read through the end of summer.

The Dodgers Reading Champions Challenge encourages 1st-8th graders to read daily and log their minutes online. Children track their reading minutes online and must achieve a goal of 15-30 minutes read per day in order to be recognized as a Dodgers Reading Champion (450–900+ minutes in any given month). Children with 450–899 minutes read have a chance to win a Dodger prize pack, and children with 900+ minutes have a chance to win special Dodger prizes including pregame recognition on the field at Dodger Stadium!

To sign up, visit: https://www.mlb.com/dodgers/community/la-reads

Burbank Police Department
December 17, 2019 at 3:36 PM ·

Today, the Burbank Police Department hosted the third and final "Character Counts" reward lunch at local Burbank Unified School District middle schools. This program was launched to encourage and reinforce the importance of good behavior and character, while emphasizing and promoting a positive school climate.

Today's final recognition was held at Luther Burbank Middle School, where students from grades 6, 7 and 8 were treated to a pizza and ice cream lunch with Burbank Police Officers. These students were nominated by teachers for living up to the six pillars of character: Trustworthiness, Respect, Responsibility, Fairness, Caring, and Citizenship.

The Burbank Police Department would like to thank Blaze Pizza and Stefan Doomanis - Realtor of Barry Burnett Realty for their generous support for this program and for donating the food, ice cream, and refreshments for the reward lunch.

The Burbank Police Department hopes to continue and expand this program in the future. Congratulations to all!

Dear Parents, Guardians, Community Members, and BUSD Staff,

I am communicating to inform you that we received information that students have heard about a non-credible threat that was made on a fake BUSD Instagram account. There was a post about a threat to John Burroughs High School. (This Instagram post has since been taken down). We are working with the Burbank Police Department to monitor this site and take appropriate action.

Please note that we take all threats seriously. If someone sees or hears something that is out of the ordinary, they need to report it to school administrators and/or the police. These types of threats are unlawful, regardless of intention, and may result in serious criminal and civil consequences that include possible financial restitution for hours spent on investigations.

Sincerely,
Matt Hill, Ed.D.
Superintendent

Guy Myers Honored as Teacher of the Year

The Los Angeles County Office of Education recognized various outstanding teachers at the Teacher of the Year luncheon held earlier today. Our very own Guy Myers was honored as the Burbank Unified Teacher of the Year.

Mr. Myers teaches Drama at John Burroughs High School. He is respected, admired, skillful, and dedicated; his students, their parents, his colleagues, his administrators, and his community in general are incredibly fortunate to work with him. He shows students how work should be done through example. He is an exceptional educator, role model teacher, and independent thinker. Not only is he amazing at his job in teaching drama, but he encourages and enables students to become independent thinkers who get inspired by his teaching to do more, become more and make an impact on the world. Burbank Unified is proud to have Mr. Myers represent the Burbank Unified School District during today’s event. The professionalism, enthusiasm, and leadership he brings to John Burroughs High School (JBHS) is second to none.
